awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Online Safe Reinforcement Learning for Wireless Resource Allocation
awd_abstract_narration:
Next generation wireless networks are being engineered to meet a complex mix of application requirements, from traditional mobile broadband (e.g., web browsing, video streaming) to new emerging applications (e.g., augmented reality, self-driving cars, industrial automation, robotics) with heterogeneous much more stringent reliability-latency requirements.  The ability to support these requirements drives the potential to deliver the new business models and new revenue streams that would enable deployments of the new technology. Thus, wireless scheduling and resource allocation will take center stage in terms of enabling technologies for such networks.  Meanwhile reinforcement learning (RL) using deep networks has emerged as a powerful framework to devise polices that optimize complex systems' performance (including wireless systems); however, these usually do not come with any formal guarantees.  The central thesis of this research is that RL-based resource allocation policies without operational guarantees, e.g., throughput-optimality/stability, are unlikely to be accepted and/or deployed, thus a key requirement to make these techniques usable, is to develop approaches which ensure safety guarantees. The research advances the state-of-the-art in safe reinforcement learning, with specific applications to wireless systems, but also is expected to benefit other application domains as well as society more broadly, through planned efforts in education, innovation, achieving diversity, engaging the community and industry, and disseminating results to a wider public.

This research centers on the development and analysis of a safe reinforcement learning (Safe-RL) framework, which optimizes rewards over short-time scales, and also provides theoretically strong long-term throughput-optimality guarantees for state-of-art wireless scheduling algorithms.  The key underlying observation is that many of today's scheduling algorithms derive their performance guarantees from Lyapunov analysis.  The project leverages the innovative concept of guardrails -- constraints on the state-dependent actions of Safe-RL -- that guarantee that the wireless system's Lyapunov evolution stay within a bounded perturbation of classical algorithms.  This guarantee, in turn, ensures that Safe-RL has safety/stability properties of state-of-the-art schedulers, while leveraging RL to realize complex performance tradeoffs.  The research consists of three inter-related thrusts.  Thrust 1 develops the foundations and representations for safe-RL at the core of this project, along with a theoretical basis for safety guarantees and new classes of efficient learning for wireless system network abstractions.  Thrust 2 focuses on the application of safe-RL theory to wireless resource allocation, including addressing challenges associated with joint scheduling of real-time and broadband traffic, learning and exploiting traffic patterns, and an exploration of the degree to which a policy hits guardrails as an indication of system anomalies or need for re-optimization.  Thrust 3 centers on the challenging but necessary task of validating the safe-RL framework leveraging an industrial strength multi-cell simulator.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The central goal of this project was to develop and analyze machine learning based approaches to address complex wireless scheduling and resource allocation problems. A particular focus of our proposed work was to explore (1) how one might ensure safety / performance guarantees when such systems are deployed in the wild, i.e., unknown environments and (2) develop and/or infer efficient network abstractions that facilitate efficient resource sharing. Our main findings might be summarized in three core areas.

First, in the context of general queueing systems, of which wireless scheduling is a special case, we developed a new concept denoted the meta-scheduling framework which addresses the need for safety guarantees when learned policies are deployed in new environments. The proposed policy essentially switches amongst a set of pre-established schedulers where some may be unproven learning-based schedulers while at least one of the others corresponds to a traditional “safe” scheduler with theoretical guarantees e.g., on stability but not necessarily performance optimal. Our meta scheduler switching policy ensures that the best scheduler, in terms of a predefined performance/rewards, is eventually used and thus the performance of the deployed system will always be as good as a traditional scheduler but if other policies being considered are better, they will be in effect.  This produces a method to achieve best-in-class performance while ensuring that the overall system is stable (aka “safe”). In general, wireless systems must address heterogeneous traffic and requirements and thus they are usually engineered with a parametrized hierarchical scheduler which addresses amongst sets of users across these sets. As part of this research, we were able to extend the main ideas underlying the meta scheduler concept to allow a system to optimize the hierarchical schedulers parameters to achieve the best overall system performance. 

The second core area findings we propose and show that online algorithms can be used to learn how partial information of wireless channel characteristics relates to the capacity that a current set of wireless users can achieve. The ability to infer what is possible is critical to devising effective resource allocation yet is quite challenging since only limited and quantized channel information is available to the base station.  

To that end we developed an online clustering approach to represent the channel capacity region, and thus allows dimensionality-reduction in the map from the vector channel state (vector of users) to the corresponding set of rates that can be scheduled. An extensive validation of the proposed techniques based on an industry strength cellular network simulator provide high confidence in the capacity representations our algorithm can learn to represent specific wireless environments. 

In the third area of findings, we studied how to practically address the challenges associated with resource allocation in systems that are coupled through interference, i.e.., where one base station’s scheduling decision impacts that of another and so forth. To that end we developed the theoretical foundations for online algorithms where distributed decisions are ``weakly coupled” and showed that under such assumptions one can devise strategies that are effective.
